A man wishes to cross the river with a wolf, a goat, and some hay (don't ask me why!) He has a small boat, but unfortunately, he can only take one thing across at a time. What is worse, if he leaves the wolf and the goat alone together, the wolf will eat the goat, and if he leaves the goat with the hay, the goat will eat the hay. How does he do it?

Explain solution to this riddle to five years old

To cross the river with the wolf, the goat, the hay, and the small boat, you need to find a good balance between taking only one thing at a time and leaving them all together.

So, the man has to find a way to make sure he doesn't leave the wolf and the goat together, or the goat will eat the hay, and the wolf will eat the goat.

One way to do this is to put the hay in a pile next to the river, so it's out of the way when the goat starts eating it.

The man can also try to leave the goat with the hay in a nearby meadow or grassy area, so it has a safe place to eat the hay.

But the best way to do this is to be really careful about leaving any of them alone together, because that could lead to a really big problem.
